report_title: Business Process Outsourcing Services Industry Report
executive_summary: BPO companies have fared well recently, supported by a strong economy and rising demand in the human resource, finance, accounting and insurance sectors, collectively generating a large portion of BPO business. Also, rising wages and increased operating costs associated with healthcare expansion helped drive employers to BPO companies as a method of cost control. Nonetheless, rising wages have cut into BPO companies' profit. Revenue has been growing at a CAGR of 1.7% to an estimated $73.0 billion over the past five years, with revenue expected to inch upward 0.7% in 2024. Mixed economic outcomes, coupled with a higher frequency of layoffs from finance and insurance clients, has caused profit to slip and resulted in smaller contracts for BPO companies.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Economic Volatility Slowed Growth, But Rapid Economic Recovery Boosted Operators
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The outbreak of the pandemic slowed the growth of BPO companies. Overall, falling corporate profit and reductions in the number of businesses stifled growth for BPO companies in 2020. Nonetheless, some service providers benefitted from the outbreak. Downstream markets demanded human resources services to help transition to remote work following stay-at-home orders and social distancing measures. The healthcare sector increasingly needed BPO companies for compliance and billing support.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Rising Wage Costs Attracted Clients to BPO Companies
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: One of the primary benefits of using BPO services is the cost savings associated with wages and health benefits. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, benefits, including health-related benefits, account for 29.4% of employers' costs, incentivizing many companies to use BPO companies' services. Surging inflation led wage costs to rise, while not in line with inflation, attracting clients to BPO companies to reduce these costs.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: An Uptick in Demand for Human Resource Services Amid Layoffs to Have Mixed Effects
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Financial services and tech companies have laid off many employees in 2022 and 2023 largely for cost-cutting imperatives amid overstaffing, benefitting BPOs. According to Bloomberg, 28.0% of tech layoffs were HR and recruiting roles, leading to increased HR services BPO companies have been and will continue to provide. While BPO companies have enjoyed an increase in providing various services amid layoffs, economic uncertainty and falling corporate profit have led to shorter contracts, overall price reductions and smaller contracts, subduing revenue growth in 2023.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Supply Chain Woes Spurred Growth from Downstream Markets
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Utilities and energy companies have increasingly sought out BPO companies to enhance supplier relationships and efficiencies as fuel costs climbed and hindered their profit. The great resignation attracted utilities and energy companies to BPO companies to provide human resource services for hiring and training. Manufacturers increasingly sought BPO companies' supply chain management services and sales fulfillment to increase operational efficiency as they faced considerably higher input costs and other related issues.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Expansion of Remote Work Enhances Operator Efficiency
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: With many clients transitioning to some form of hybrid work following the pandemic, more remote opportunities have arisen to enhance operator efficiency. The proliferation of remote work among core clients, particularly in the banking and insurance sectors, enabled many business process outsourcing operators to shift toward remote work and engage with clients virtually. This has proven to be especially helpful, as recent spikes in inflation have accelerated many operational costs, so operators have been able to procure workers from a variety of locations around the world and conduct their services more efficiently.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Layoffs Will Continue to Present an Opportunity for BPO Companies
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Economic uncertainty surrounding inflation and interest rate hikes has led financial services and tech companies to ramp up layoffs in 2024 as they slowed hiring to reduce costs. Tech companies have laid off many human resource workers and financial services companies have laid off back-office staff. These layoffs will present BPO companies with an opportunity as services like compliance, human resources and accounting are cheaper to outsource than perform in-house. While BPOs will enjoy an uptick in outsourcing services, economic uncertainty surrounding these layoffs isn't wholly beneficial as it can bring about shorter contracts, overall price reductions and smaller deals, potentially subduing revenue growth moving forward.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Profit Will Continue To Struggle, But Innovations Will Offset Some Losses
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Over the next five years, BPO companies' profit will continue to struggle as wage costs continue to surge, with heightened interest rates continuing to bolster operational expenses. As financial services and tech companies ramp up layoffs, BPOs will increase their workforce to manage the uptick in services they provide, increasing incentive-based payouts to attract workers and hindering profit. While artificial intelligence and automated systems aren't perfect yet, developments in this technology will allow BPO companies to reduce wage costs. As BPO companies increasingly invest in new technologies, they will become more vertically integrated, increasing operational efficiencies and reducing other costs like accounting, taking some pressure off climbing wage costs.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: BPO Companies Will Have To Adapt To Compete
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As consumers increasingly demand IT-integrated solutions and look for a one-stop shop for BPO services, BPO companies must adapt to meet their clients' needs. Global BPO companies with IT-integrated solutions are a considerable threat to traditional BPO companies as these solutions provide more accurate and quality results than traditional BPO companies. IT-integrated solutions can provide clients with real-time monitoring and analytics. IT-integrated solutions can also provide greater data security, attracting clients as data security concerns constantly increase. Adopting IT-integrated solutions is complex and challenging, so this trend will be a pain point for traditional BPO companies over the outlook period.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: BPOs to enjoy growth from healthcare providers
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As healthcare companies continue digitizing their records, they will seek out BPO companies' services to manage their health records. Healthcare companies will seek out BPO companies capable of securing the privacy of these records, so BPO companies must be able to provide IT-integrated solutions to attract these clients. As new virus variants continue to emerge, the need for compliance checkers may increase as healthcare providers face increased billing and compliance needs amid overrun hospitals. As the number of available health insurance plans continues to increase and become more complex, healthcare providers will seek out BPO companies to ensure their operations run efficiently.

industry_definition: Operators in this industry provide third-party outsourcing services on a contract basis. Clients can outsource specific operations and business functions, including both back and front office tasks, to companies in this industry.

negative_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: low - steady

key_trends: BPO companies primarily compete based on price. Service offerings and quality are other significant sources of competition for BPO companies.
BPOs face stiff external competition. Customers can establish contracts with international companies that provide services for cheaper or perform services in-house.

BPO companies have enjoyed growth despite some headwinds. Despite falling corporate profit during the pandemic and high inflationary pressures slowing growth, overall increased use of BPO companies led to expansion.

Growth will remain strong but slow. As BPO companies come off the heels of smaller contracts late over the current period amid economic uncertainty and falling corporate profit, growth will slow. Still, downstream customers' attraction to IT-integrated solutions will bolster BPO companies.

Just two companies amassed greater than 5.0% of the market. Accenture PLC and Conduent Business Services LLC accumulated this market share by being on the cutting edge of technology and offering various services.

market_segmentation.segment_description: This segment comprises small to large banking and insurance companies. In the years following the financial crisis, the banking and insurance sectors have faced higher levels of scrutiny, leading them to seek more customer-focused services.

This segment comprises small to large banking and insurance companies. In the years following the financial crisis, the banking and insurance sectors have faced higher levels of scrutiny, leading them to seek more customer-focused services.

This market comprises pharmaceutical companies and healthcare providers. Hospitals were overrun amid the pandemic, increasing the need for compliance checkers as healthcare providers faced an uptick in billing and compliance needs. Pharmaceutical companies looked to BPO companies when developing vaccines and treatments in response to the pandemic to reduce costs.

This market comprises consumer packaged goods and manufacturing companies. Consumer packaged goods companies and manufacturers require high operational efficiency, so both use BPO services for cost-saving solutions.

This market comprises consumer packaged goods and manufacturing companies. Consumer packaged goods companies and manufacturers require high operational efficiency, so both use BPO services for cost-saving solutions.

This market comprises software and telecommunication companies. Software and telecommunication companies are using BPO companies to provide vertically integrated solutions so they can focus on higher-value processes.

This segment comprises companies in the energy and utilities sector. As rising fuel costs cut into profit, utilities and energy companies hire BPO companies to enhance supplier relationships and efficiencies. Labor shortages have also led utilities and energy companies to BPO companies to provide human resource services for hiring and training.

This market comprises other markets like the public sector. The public sector, including federal, state and municipal governments and agencies, has been slow to adopt the infrastructure and invest in outsourced professional services, hindering growth in this market.

products_and_services.product_description: This segment comprises warranty management, sales fulfillment, document management, public service processing, communications, supply chains and engineering services.
This segment comprises the third-party completion of personnel processes like talent acquisition, talent development, current employee services and compensation.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Customer Relationship Management Business Process Outsourcing Services
products_and_services.product_description: This segment comprises customer care, technical support and help desk, call centers, social and media practices, sales and marketing efforts and customer analytics.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Financial and Accounting Business Process Outsourcing Services
products_and_services.product_description: This segment comprises financial and accounting service providers.

tier_1_suppliers: Office Supply Stores in the US
Internet Service Providers in the US
tier_1_buyers: Healthcare and Social Assistance in the US
Finance and Insurance in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Corporate profit measures the amount of profit earned across all industries within the US. Increased corporate profit enables businesses to spend more on outsourcing, directing added work to specialized companies and contributing to more significant revenue. Conversely, falling corporate profit indicates slumping performance among corporations and weaker macroeconomic conditions, posing a potential threat to the industry.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Number of businesses refers to the total
demand_determinants.determinant_description: The number of businesses refers to the total number of companies within the United States with one or more employees. A rise in the total number of businesses increases the number of businesses that may use BPO services which benefits BPO companies. Conversely, declines in the number of businesses shrinks the potential marketplace for operators and creates higher competition among the existing client pool.

Rising demand for private health and medical insurance facilitates increased BPO services. As health and medical insurance provisions have become increasingly complex, demand for outsourced specialization in these services has also risen over the past five years. In addition, an increase in business healthcare expenditures may encourage companies to hire overseas to reduce costs, representing a potential opportunity for the industry.

business_locations.location_description: Many BPO services favor the Southeast due to a robust population presence, which provides a substantial downstream market and a sizable workforce for these companies. Florida is particularly attractive to BPO companies. The state hosts a significant number of call centers and human resource services, making it a popular destination for BPOs.

California continues to make up a significant portion of BPOs due to its robust population presence and significant demand from downstream technology clients. High-tech and software companies invest heavily in research and development, attracting BPOs that offer vertically integrated solutions and enabling clients to focus on higher-value business activities, boosting BPO popularity.

The Mid-Atlantic attracts various sectors to establish BPO companies. New Jersey, in particular, benefits from significant telecommunications operations, making it a preferred location. New York City hosts a high concentration of major clients, making it a prime spot for BPO services. With its status as a national and regional powerhouse, New York attracts a wide range of clients that provide critical demand for BPOs.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Historically, regulations governing companies providing business process outsourcing services were pretty generic and applicable to most domestic industries. These include laws addressing advertising and branding practices.

The desire to protect confidential personal information has been the primary driver of anti-outsourcing bills. One notable piece of legislation is the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA), which covers electronically stored or transmitted health information. As BPO companies increasingly provide cloud computing services, regulators will implement more personal confidentiality legislation.

With the previous financial crisis, the regulation of outsourcing regarding financial information has also strengthened. Specifically, the Dodd-Frank Act has created and empowered regulatory bodies like the Financial Stability Oversight Council and the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority (FINRA). The Bank Service Corporation Act stipulates that third-party providers of outsourced services to FDIC-insured banks are subject to supervision by federal bank regulators. The Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act (GLBA) covers electronically stored financial information.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) released a series of business guidelines in response to COVID-19. For example, employees who appear to have symptoms must be separated from work, while employees who test positive must inform fellow employees of their possible exposure. Businesses are encouraged to maintain extra precautions for employees at higher risk for severe illness, like older adults and those with chronic medical conditions.

basis_points.basis_title: BPO companies primarily compete based on price.
basis_points.basis_description: BPO companies primarily compete based on price. Service offerings and quality are other significant sources of competition for BPO companies.
BPOs face stiff external competition. Customers can establish contracts with international companies that provide services for cheaper or perform services in-house.

concentration_points.concentration_title: The high number of small-scale BPO companies keeps concentration low.
concentration_points.concentration_description: The majority of BPO companies are small-scale nonemployers or companies with few employees. These companies typically offer niche services and don't possess the scale to accumulate considerable market share.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Large multinational companies are expanding their presence.
concentration_points.concentration_description: Market share concentration has recently increased as the global presence of the largest BPO companies such as Accenture, gives them an advantage over smaller companies.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Accounting, insurance, bank services and legal fees
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Some of the other costs incurred by operators include those associated with accounting, insurance, bank services and legal fees.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: New entrants need strong connections for sourcing skilled yet inexpensive foreign labor. Additionally, they require staff with a high level of business knowledge pertaining to the labor's country of origin.

volatility_points.volatility_title: The health of the economy impacts volatility.
volatility_points.volatility_description: Since choosing to outsource business operations is part of a long-term strategy, small to midsize companies focus more on short-term plans during economic downturns. Shorter contracts, overall price reductions and smaller deals from small to midsize companies result from economic downturns. Financial service clients begin to consolidate and change corporate strategies in response to troubled markets and increase contract terminations with outsourcing companies.

volatility_points.volatility_title: The level of technological change induces volatility.
volatility_points.volatility_description: BPO companies enjoy growth with technological changes as clients want access to the best, cutting-edge tools for their business. Changes in available technology enable BPO companies to expand into untapped markets and offer new services, inducing revenue volatility.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: CLOUD COMPUTING WILL PROVIDE BPOS WITH AN AVENUE FOR GROWTH.
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Cloud computing allows users to access information from multiple platforms and improve operational efficiencies. Clients have increasingly sought out BPO companies for their expertise in maintaining cloud computing software. BPO companies providing cloud computing services will continue to enjoy strong growth.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: BPOS ARE USING ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE AND AUTOMATED SYSTEMS TO IMPROVE EFFICIENCIES.
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: BPO companies can use artificial intelligence and automated systems to reduce wage costs and increase operational efficiencies, enabling them to improve profit and better compete based on price. These technologies are not yet perfect, but as they continue to develop and improve, BPO companies will benefit. This increased use of this technology among BPO companies will ramp up competition and those that don't adopt it will fall behind.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in a niche service or bundle its services to attract clients?
FAQs.answer: Business process outsourcing companies look to provide a variety of services to help businesses reduce their operating costs and maximize efficiency.

FAQs.question: How do you market your services to potential clients? Is there a heavy reliance on long-term contracts or repeat clients?
FAQs.answer: The largest companies rely heavily on long-term contracts with repeat customers; however, this is less important for smaller companies who can carve out a market niche.

FAQs.question: Does your company target a particular market segment, or provide for a broad range of markets?
FAQs.answer: Business process outsourcing companies provide services to businesses of all sizes, across all sectors; this provides them with relatively steady demand and minimal revenue volatility.

FAQs.question: Has your company implemented practices to lower purchasing costs?
FAQs.answer: As business process outsourcing firms require computers and related office equipment to provide their services, their ability to minimize purchases is relatively low.

FAQs.question: Does your business use web-based systems for customer bookings or orders?
FAQs.answer: Assisting with cloud computing implementation and other digital services has become a growing source of revenue for companies, as more companies seek to use cloud-based services to minimize operating costs.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce costs by automating operations?
FAQs.answer: While some companies have started using software to minimize labor, they still heavily rely on skilled workers to perform services; this is unlikely to change soon.

FAQs.question: Do regulations pertinent to your business vary from state to state?
FAQs.answer: Companies are subject to minimal direct regulation, so they are generally not hampered by regulations that vary between states.

FAQs.question: Is your business responsible for safeguarding customer information?
FAQs.answer: Business process outsourcing firms must safeguard information given to them by clients, as the nature of the information they handle is highly personal.

FAQs.question: How frequently does your company purchase new equipment?
FAQs.answer: There is minimal equipment needed by business process outsourcing firms to provide their services, leading to low depreciation costs.

FAQs.question: How does your company compensate for seasonality of cash flow?
FAQs.answer: As business process outsourcing firms provide their services to all types of businesses across the economy, their cash flow is relatively consistent.

FAQs.question: Can you access high-quality personnel management? What specialized training and skills do employees need?
FAQs.answer: To provide services and remain competitive, service providers need to have access to high-quality personnel management.

FAQs.question: How often do you invest in research and development? How quickly can you adopt new technology?
FAQs.answer: Service providers need to constantly find new and better ways to apply the increased functionality and flexibility of technology, to improve services and pass on savings to customers.

FAQs.question: How many online courses do you offer? How have students responded to the online courses you offer?
FAQs.answer: Successful service providers offer products with an accessible client user interface through the use of web-based technology.

FAQs.question: What proportion of your services are to the professional, scientific and technical sector? How do you maintain relationships with buyers?
FAQs.answer: Companies in these industries are responsible for large amounts of sensitive client and proprietary data. As a result, many employees are required to conduct essential back-office functions related to record maintenance, settlements and regulatory compliance.

FAQs.question: Do you have a way of tracking the number of people with health insurance? How do you plan for volatile demand from the health insurance market?
FAQs.answer: As health and medical insurance provisions have become increasingly complex, demand for outsourced specialization in these services has also risen.

FAQs.question: How have changes in corporate profit affected your company's revenue? Have you implemented any pricing changes in order to attract customers?
FAQs.answer: Greater corporate profit enables businesses to spend more on outsourcing, directing added work to specialized companies and contributing to greater revenue.
